description: From Middle English grunten, from Old English grunnettan (“to grunt”), from Proto-West Germanic *grunnattjan, from Proto-Germanic *grunnatjaną (“to grunt”), frequentative of Proto-Germanic *grunnōną (“to grunt”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰrun- (“to shout”).
Cognate with German grunzen (“to grunt”), Danish grynte (“to grunt”). The noun senses are all instances of zero derivation from the verb.

entries.meaning: A short snorting sound, often to show disapproval, or used as a reply when one is reluctant to speak.
The snorting cry of a pig.
Any fish of the perciform family Haemulidae.
A person who does ordinary and boring work.
(slang) The amount of power of which a vehicle is capable.
examples: The engine might not possess quite as much grunt as the later 24v six, but it delivers invigorating performance  […]

entries.meaning: (Canada, US) A dessert of steamed berries and dough, usually blueberries; blueberry grunt.

verbs.description: grunt (third-person singular simple present grunts, present participle grunting, simple past and past participle grunted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a person) To make a grunt or grunts.
(intransitive, of a pig) To make a grunt or grunts.
(intransitive, UK, slang) To break wind; to fart.
